answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
In order to facilitate discussion, I have located a few documents that I found relevant to the question asked.
There was a question asked on July 27, 2010 about examples of successful mixed use facilities as described by ICMA’s publication. The individual asking the question give the example of Albuquerque, New Mexico’s high school being converted into “The Lofts at Albuquerque High.” Another individual who answered the question also gave an example of the conversion of an old high school into a housing complex for the elderly:
http://bit.ly/ie4JYk
Additionally, there have been a few award nominees and recipients of ICMA’s Community Sustainability Award that seem to have developed programs that are consistent with the goals of the Smart Growth in rural communities document. Although they may have been created before the article was published, they still serve as good examples of what communities are capable of.
In Germantown, Tennessee the City Administrator created a program that helps city officials determine whether or not development project meet Smart Growth priorities while also achieving something they call the “Triple Bottom Line” They describe the “Triple Bottom Line” as something that achieves financial sustainability, environmental stewardship, and community building. If officials find that a proposed project meets all of these criteria it is eligible for a financial incentive package:
http://bit.ly/frsFyz
There was also the development project that won the Community Sustainability Award, City of the Sun (Stad van de Zon). In Heerhugowaard, The Netherlands the City Manager created a housing development that incorporates solar energy and sustainable water systems into everyday life: 
http://bit.ly/eR1ZbN
I hope this helps,
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org
